info.name: API misupermercado
info.description: # ðŸš€ Get started here This template guides you through CRUD operations (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), variables, and tests. ## ðŸ”– **How to use this template** #### **Step 1: Send requests** RESTful APIs allow you to perform CRUD operations using the POST, GET, PUT, and DELETE HTTP methods. This collection contains each of these [request](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/requests/) types. Open each request and click "Send" to see what happens. #### **Step 2: View responses** Observe the response tab for status code (200 OK), response time, and size. #### **Step 3: Send new Body data** Update or add new data in "Body" in the POST request. Typically, Body data is also used in PUT request. ``` { "name": "Add your name in the body" } ``` #### **Step 4: Update the variable** Variables enable you to store and reuse values in Postman. We have created a [variable](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/) called `base_url` with the sample request [https://postman-api-learner.glitch.me](https://postman-api-learner.glitch.me). Replace it with your API endpoint to customize this collection. #### **Step 5: Add tests in the "Scripts" tab** Adding tests to your requests can help you confirm that your API is working as expected. You can write test scripts in JavaScript and view the output in the "Test Results" tab. ## ðŸ’ª Pro tips - Use folders to group related requests and organize the collection. - Add more [scripts](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/intro-to-scripts/) to verify if the API works as expected and execute workflows. ## ðŸ’¡Related templates [API testing basics](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=e9a37a28-055b-49cd-8c7e-97494a21eb54&sourceTemplateId=ddb19591-3097-41cf-82af-c84273e56719) [API documentation](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=e9c28f47-1253-44af-a2f3-20dce4da1f18&sourceTemplateId=ddb19591-3097-41cf-82af-c84273e56719) [Authorization methods](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=31a9a6ed-4cdf-4ced-984c-d12c9aec1c27&sourceTemplateId=ddb19591-3097-41cf-82af-c84273e56719)

request.description:
### Response

The successful response will have a `200 OK` status and will return a JSON array containing client objects.

``` json
[
  {
    "id_cliente": "number",
    "apellidoNombre": "string",
    "dni": "string",
    "fechaNacimiento": "string",
    "correoElectronico": "string",
    "contrasena": "string"
  }
]

 ```

This JSON schema represents the structure of the response data, with each client object containing the specified keys and their respective data types.

response.name: clientes (GET)

request.description:
This endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to search for clients by name. The request should include the name of the client as a path parameter in the URL.

### Response

The response for this request is a JSON array containing objects with the following properties:

- `id_cliente` (number): The unique identifier of the client.
    
- `apellidoNombre` (string): The last name and first name of the client.
    
- `dni` (string): The national identification number of the client.
    
- `fechaNacimiento` (string): The date of birth of the client.
    
- `correoElectronico` (string): The email address of the client.
    
- `contrasena` (string): The password of the client.
    

``` json
[
  {
    "id_cliente": 0,
    "apellidoNombre": "",
    "dni": "",
    "fechaNacimiento": "",
    "correoElectronico": "",
    "contrasena": ""
  }
]

 ```

This is a POST request, submitting data to an API via the request body. This request submits JSON data, and the data is reflected in the response.

A successful POST request typically returns a `200 OK` or `201 Created` response code.

This is a PUT request and it is used to overwrite an existing piece of data. For instance, after you create an entity with a POST request, you may want to modify that later. You can do that using a PUT request. You typically identify the entity being updated by including an identifier in the URL (eg. `id=1`).

A successful PUT request typically returns a `200 OK`, `201 Created`, or `204 No Content` response code.

This is a GET request to retrieve a list of products from the specified endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but query parameters can be used to specify the resource to retrieve.

### Example

``` json
[
    {
        "id_producto": 0,
        "producto": "",
        "precio": 0
    }
]

 ```

A successful response will have a `200 OK` status and will include an array of product objects, each containing an `id_producto`, `producto`, and `precio`.

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

This is a POST request, submitting data to an API via the request body. This request submits JSON data, and the data is reflected in the response.

A successful POST request typically returns a `200 OK` or `201 Created` response code.

This is a PUT request and it is used to overwrite an existing piece of data. For instance, after you create an entity with a POST request, you may want to modify that later. You can do that using a PUT request. You typically identify the entity being updated by including an identifier in the URL (eg. `id=1`).

A successful PUT request typically returns a `200 OK`, `201 Created`, or `204 No Content` response code.

### Delete Product

This endpoint is used to delete a specific product by its identifier.

#### Request

- Method: `DELETE`
    
- URL: `{{dominio}}/api/productos/2`
    

#### Response

The response for this request is a JSON schema with the following properties:

- `message` (string): A message indicating the result of the delete operation.
    

Example:

``` json
{
    "message": "Product deleted successfully"
}

 ```

exec: pm.test("Response time is less than 200ms", function () {

request.description:
### Get Ordenes de Compra

This endpoint retrieves a list of purchase orders.

#### Request

- Method: GET
    
- URL: `{{dominio}}/api/ordenes-compra`
    

#### Response

- Status: 200
    
- Content-Type: application/json
    
- \[ { "id_orden": 0, "fecha": "", "cliente": { "id_cliente": 0, "apellidoNombre": "", "dni": "", "fechaNacimiento": "", "correoElectronico": "", "contrasena": "" }, "importe": 0, "domicilioEntrega": "", "horaEntrega": "" }\]
    

\[  
{  
"id_orden": 0,  
"fecha": "",  
"cliente": {  
"id_cliente": 0,  
"apellidoNombre": "",  
"dni": "",  
"fechaNacimiento": "",  
"correoElectronico": "",  
"contrasena": ""  
},  
"importe": 0,  
"domicilioEntrega": "",  
"horaEntrega": ""  
}  
\]

request.description:
### Create New Order

This endpoint allows you to create a new order for a client.

#### Request Body

- `id_orden` (integer) - The ID of the order.
    
- `fecha` (string) - The date and time of the order.
    
- `cliente` (object) - The client details including ID, name, date of birth, email, and password.
    
    - `id_cliente` (integer) - The ID of the client.
        
    - `apellidoNombre` (string) - The full name of the client.
        
    - `dni` (string) - The client's identification number.
        
    - `fechaNacimiento` (string) - The client's date of birth.
        
    - `correoElectronico` (string) - The client's email address.
        
    - `contrasena` (string) - The client's password.
        
- `importe` (number) - The order amount.
    
- `domicilioEntrega` (string) - The delivery address.
    
- `horaEntrega` (string) - The delivery time.
    

#### Response

The response will be in the following JSON schema:

``` json
{
  "id_orden": "integer",
  "fecha": "string",
  "cliente": {
    "id_cliente": "integer",
    "apellidoNombre": "string",
    "dni": "string",
    "fechaNacimiento": "string",
    "correoElectronico": "string",
    "contrasena": "string"
  },
  "importe": "number",
  "domicilioEntrega": "string",
  "horaEntrega": "string"
}

 ```

}

request.description:
This endpoint allows you to update an existing purchase order by sending an HTTP PUT request to the specified URL. The request should include the updated order details in the request body.

### Request Body

- id_orden: The ID of the order to be updated (integer)
    
- fecha: The updated date of the order (string, format: "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.MMMZ")
    
- cliente: An object containing the details of the customer
    
    - id_cliente: The ID of the customer (integer)
        
    - apellidoNombre: The updated name of the customer (string)
        
    - dni: The updated identification number of the customer (string)
        
    - fechaNacimiento: The updated date of birth of the customer (string, format: "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.MMMZ")
        
    - correoElectronico: The updated email address of the customer (string)
        
    - contrasena: The updated password of the customer (string)
        
- importe: The updated total amount of the order (number)
    
- domicilioEntrega: The updated delivery address (string)
    
- horaEntrega: The updated delivery time (string)
    

### Response

The response will be in the form of a JSON schema, with the following structure:  
{  
"id_orden": 0,  
"fecha": "",  
"cliente": {  
"id_cliente": 0,  
"apellidoNombre": "",  
"dni": "",  
"fechaNacimiento": "",  
"correoElectronico": "",  
"contrasena": ""  
},  
"importe": 0,  
"domicilioEntrega": "",  
"horaEntrega": ""  
}  
The response will contain the updated details of the purchase order, with the corresponding data types as mentioned above.

request.description:
This endpoint sends an HTTP DELETE request to the specified URL to delete the purchase order with the ID 6.

### Response

The response of this request is a JSON schema representing the structure of the response data.

request.description:
This endpoint allows you to update the details of a specific purchase identified by the ID "1". The request should be sent as an HTTP PUT to {{dominio}}/api/detalles-compra/1. The request body should include the details of the purchase, such as the ID of the detail, order, product, price, quantity ordered, and total amount. The request body should be in JSON format.

### Request Body

- `id_detalle` (number): The ID of the detail.
    
- `orden` (object): Details of the order including order ID, date, customer details, total amount, delivery address, and delivery time.
    
    - `id_orden` (number): The ID of the order.
        
    - `fecha` (string): The date of the order.
        
    - `cliente` (object): Customer details including customer ID, name, ID number, date of birth, email, and password.
        
        - `id_cliente` (number): The ID of the customer.
            
        - `apellidoNombre` (string): The name of the customer.
            
        - `dni` (string): The ID number of the customer.
            
        - `fechaNacimiento` (string): The date of birth of the customer.
            
        - `correoElectronico` (string): The email of the customer.
            
        - `contrasena` (string): The password of the customer.
            
    - `importe` (number): The total amount of the order.
        
    - `domicilioEntrega` (string): The delivery address.
        
    - `horaEntrega` (string): The delivery time.
        
- `producto` (object): Details of the product including product ID, name, and price.
    
    - `id_producto` (number): The ID of the product.
        
    - `producto` (string): The name of the product.
        
    - `precio` (number): The price of the product.
        
- `precio` (number): The price of the purchase.
    
- `cantidadPedida` (number): The quantity ordered.
    
- `importe` (number): The total amount.
    

### Response

The response will include the updated details of the purchase. The response body will be in JSON format and will include the same fields as the request body, with updated values based on the changes made.

``` json
    "horaEntrega": ""

    "producto": "",
    "precio": 0
  },
  "precio": 0,
  "cantidadPedida": 0,
  "importe": 0
}

 ```
